body:
As discussed [on Discord](https://discord.com/channels/691052431525675048/1354184220263841812/1359585787846328441) with @NthTensor, this is due to Rust 2024, and is not our bug. It's arguably not a bug at all!

See https://doc.rust-lang.org/edition-guide/rust-2024/never-type-fallback.html for the context on this change, which recommends the same workaround of explicitly specifying the return type. The same code will compile just fine as functions rather than closures, because the return type of functions is never inferred (even if it's defaulted to ()).
Actually, reopening this to track the fix in the same issue: we should be able to just implement these traits for functions which return the `!` (never) type.

I think closure observers that panic are super rare.
I just use it in one test ðŸ™‚

issue.title: Write migration guide for 2024 edition panicking closure inference regression

repository.name: bevy-website

body: I literally just hit this in an observer test as well. It was a bit annoying because the observer worked fine with `assert!(false)` (to check that it wasn't called) but clippy wanted that changed to `panic!` which then didn't work without specifying the return type. It also means it doesn't work with `todo!()`.
Ok, after adding it clippy is complaining about "unneeded unit return type", that's extra annoying but kinda funny

> Ok, after adding it clippy is complaining about "unneeded unit return type", that's extra annoying but kinda funny

@kristoff3r can you please open a bug in clippy for this and link back to this issue?

issue.title: `unused_unit` triggers when the type annotation is needed to compile

labels.name: C-bug
labels.description: Category: Clippy is not doing the correct thing

labels.name: I-suggestion-causes-error
labels.description: Issue: The suggestions provided by this Lint cause an ICE/error when applied

labels.name: I-false-positive
labels.description: Issue: The lint was triggered on code it shouldn't have

repository.name: rust-clippy
repository.description: A bunch of lints to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code. Book: https://doc.rust-lang.org/clippy/

issue.body:
### Summary

When running the code snippet from [the 2024 edition guide](https://doc.rust-lang.org/edition-guide/rust-2024/never-type-fallback.html) it triggers the `unused_unit` lint, even though removing the type annotation will make the code stop compiling.

Encountered in https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/18778

### Lint Name

unused_unit

### Reproducer

```rust
trait Unit {}
impl Unit for () {}

fn run<R: Unit>(f: impl FnOnce() -> R) {
    f();
}


fn main() {
    run(|| -> () { todo!() });
}
```

Output
```
warning: unneeded unit return type
  --> src/main.rs:12:11
   |
12 |     run(|| -> () { todo!() });
   |           ^^^^^^ help: remove the `-> ()`
   |
   = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#unused_unit
   = note: `#[warn(clippy::unused_unit)]` on by default
```

### Version

```text

```

### Additional Labels

_No response_

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_DATA_START$${"user":"profetia"}$$TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_DATA_END -->

body:
This also applies to `app.add_systems`. I consider this a pretty nasty papercut that deserves fixing (or yelling about if we can't fix it).

> Actually, reopening this to track the fix in the same issue: we should be able to just implement these traits for functions which return the ! (never) type.

`!` is still experimental, meaning we can't write these impls.

https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2024&gist=e9074614255ca38bdd74874ba7f47acf We can't fix it yet on stable ðŸ™ƒ Definitely a "complain upstream" problem.

> This also applies to app.add_systems. I consider this a pretty nasty papercut that deserves fixing (or yelling about if we can't fix it).

Note that this regression is only for closures, so I would consider this a moderate-severity UX problem. I almost never write closures for systems / observers. It's more common for commands though.

> Note that this regression is only for closures, so I would consider this a moderate-severity UX problem. I almost never write closures for systems / observers. It's more common for commands though.

I expect the inline Observer closure use case to go up considerably when next generation Bevy UI takes off. Imo solving this is a "big deal".
